member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating the buffer size to use when retrieving an authentication token from Azure Active Directory.
member.value: Returns the buffer size in bytes.

summary.para: Defines error codes that can be associated with a .
A that indicates that there was an unknown error.
A that indicates the partition key is invalid.
Indicates that certificate for user role () is not setup.
A that indicates the Service Fabric Name already exists.
A that indicates the service already exists.
A that indicates the service group already exists.
A that indicates the application type is currently being provisioned.
A that indicates the application type already exists.
A that indicates the application already exists.
A that indicates the Service Fabric Name was not found.
A that indicates the property was not found.
A that indicates the value of the property was empty.
A that indicates the service was not found.
A that indicates the service group was not found.
A that indicates the application type was not found.
A that indicates the application type is in use.
A that indicates the application does not exist.
A that indicates the service type was not found.
A that indicates that the service manifest was not found.
A that indicates the Service Fabric Name is not empty: there are entities such as child Names, Service or Properties associated with it.
A that indicates the node was not found.
A that indicates that the node is up when it is expected to be down.
A that indicates the replica is not the primary.
A that indicates the service partition does not have write quorum.
A that indicates that the reconfiguration is currently in pending state.
A that indicates the replication queue is full.
that indicates that the replication operation is too large.
A that indicates that the atomic group is invalid.
A that indicates the service is offline.
A that indicates the partition was not found.
Two objects cannot be compared using because they describe different replica sets.
A that indicates that the service affinity chain is not supported.
A that indicates there was a write conflict.
A that indicates the application upgrade validation failed.
A that indicates that there is a mismatch in the service type.
A that indicates the service template was not found.
A that indicates the service type was already registered.
A that indicates the service type was not registered.
A that indicates the application is currently being upgraded.

member.name: F:System.Fabric.FabricErrorCode.ApplicationUpdateInProgress
member.summary: A FabricErrorCode that indicates the application is currently being updated.

summary.para: that indicates that the upgrade domain was already completed.
The specified code or Cluster Manifest version cannot be unprovisioned or used as the target of an upgrade because it has not been provisioned.
The specified code or Cluster Manifest version cannot be unprovisioned because it is either being used by the cluster or is the target of a cluster upgrade.
The specified code or Cluster Manifest version has already been provisioned in the system.
The Service Fabric cluster is already in the target code or Cluster Manifest version specified by the upgrade request.
The Service Fabric cluster is not currently being upgrade and the request is only valid during upgrade.
The Service Fabric Cluster is currently begin upgraded and the request is not valid during upgrade.
An error in the Service Fabric cluster upgrade request was discovered during pre-upgrade validation of the upgrade description and Cluster Manifest.

A that indicates the has reached the maximum number of health reports that can accept for processing. More reports will be accepted when progress is done with the currently accepted reports. By default, the can accept 10000 different reports.
A that indicates the report is stale. Returned when has a for the same entity, and with same or higher .

A that indicates the health entity is not found in the Health Store. Returned when Health Store has no reports from a Service Fabric system component on the entity or on one of the hierarchical parents. This can happen if the entity or one of its parents doesn’t exist in the Service Fabric cluster, or the reports didn’t yet arrive at the health store.
A that indicates Service Fabric service is too busy to accept requests at this time. This is a transient error.
A that indicates a communication error has occurred.
A that indicates that the gateway could not be reached. This is a transient error.
A that indicates the object was closed.
A that indicates the a Check has failed.
A that indicates the enumeration completed.
A that indicates the configuration section was not found.
A that indicates the configuration parameter was not found.
A that indicates the configuration was invalid.
A that indicates the image builder validation error as occurred.
A that indicates the replica does not exist.
A that indicates the process got deactivated.
A that indicates the process aborted.
A that indicates the address was invalid.
A that indicates the URI is invalid.
A that indicates the property value is too large.
A that indicates the directory was not found.
A that indicates the path is too long.
A that indicates the file was not found.
A that indicates that the code is not ready.
A that indicates the operation timed out.
A that indicates the operation did not completed.
A that indicates the code package was not found.
A that configuration package was not found.
A that indicates the data package was not found.
A that indicates the endpoint resource was not found.
A that indicates the credential type is invalid.
A that indicates that the X509FindType is invalid.
A that indicates that the X509 store location is invalid.
A that indicates that the X509 store name is invalid.
A that indicates that the X509 certificate thumbprint string is invalid.
A that indicates the protection level is invalid.
A that indicates that the X509 certificate store cannot be opened.
A that indicates the subject name is invalid.
A that indicates that the format of common name list string is invalid. It should be a comma separated list
A that indicates the credentials are invalid.
A that indicates the decryption failed.
A that indicates that the encryption has failed.
A that indicates the image store object was corrupted.
A that indicates that the ImageBuilder hit an unexpected error.
A that indicates that the ImageBuilder was not able to perform the operation in the specified timeout.
A that indicates that the ImageBuilder hit an AccessDeniedException when using the ImageStore.
A that indicates that the MSI file being provisioned is not valid.
A that indicates there was an ImageStoreIOEception.
A FabricErrorCode that indicates that the operation failed to acquire a lock.
A that indicates that the ServiceType was not defined in the service manifest.
The application is not currently being upgraded and the request is only valid during upgrade.
The application is already in the target version specified by an application upgrade request.
A that indicates that the key is too large.
A that indicates that the key cannot be found.
A that indicates the sequence number check failed. This usually happens when there is a conflicting operation executed on the same object which modifies the sequence number.
that indicates that the transaction is not active because it has already been committed or rolled back.
that indicates that the transaction is too large, which typically results when the transaction either contains too many operations or the size of the data being written is too large.
FabricErrorCode that indicates that one transaction can't be used by multiple threads simultaneously.

summary.para: Specifies the upgrade state when upgrading Service Fabric.
All Service Fabric enumerations have reserved Invalid flag.
Specifies that the rolling back process is in progress.
Specifies that the rolling back process has completed.
Specifies that the rolling forward process is pending.
Specifies that the rolling forward process is in progress.
Specifies that the rolling forward process has completed.
Indicates that the upgrade has failed.
Indicates the type of fault that a service reports: invalid, transient or permanent.

remarks.para: Services can report faults during runtime by using the method to indicate the type of fault.

summary.para: The type is invalid.
A permanent fault is a fault that the replica cannot recover from. This type of fault indicates that the replica can make no further progress and should be removed and replaced.

remarks.para: An example of a permanent fault would be a persistent stateful service that tries to write information to disk and determines that the disk had been removed or was unusable. Calling and reporting a permanent fault result in the service to be Aborted via IStatefulServiceReplica. or IStatelessServiceInstance. without a chance to gracefully clean up state or complete operations. Therefore, if any cleanup or other long-running work is necessary, it should be performed before is called. Note that the distinction between permanent and transient faults is useful mainly for persistent stateful services. Other than the call sequence, the effects on other service types are the same: the replica or instance is removed, all state at that replica or instance is lost, and the replica or instance is recreated, potentially in a different location.

summary.para: A transient fault indicates that there is some temporary condition which prevents the replica from making further progress or from processing further user requests.

remarks.para: An example of a transient fault is a service that determines that a portion of its state or some reference file is corrupted, but can be repaired if the service were to be re-initialized. In this case, the service uses the method to report a transient fault. Reporting a transient fault closes the service via IStatefulServiceReplica. or IStatelessServiceInstance.. Note that for stateless and stateful services, volatile transient faults are not very useful because state is not preserved across the failure. For these services, whether to use transient or permanent faults is dependent on whether the service should be gracefully closed asynchronously with cleanup or ungracefully closed with a synchronous IStatefulServiceReplica. or IStatelessServiceInstance. method.

summary.para: Gets or sets a that determines whether reports with warning state should be treated with the same severity as errors.

summary.para: Gets or sets the maximum allowed percentage of unhealthy deployed applications.

value.para: The maximum allowed percentage of unhealthy deployed applications. Allowed values are values from zero to 100.

exception.para: The specified value was outside the range of integer values from zero to 100.

remarks.para: The percentage represents the maximum tolerated percentage of deployed applications that can be unhealthy before the application is considered in error. This is calculated by dividing the number of unhealthy deployed applications over the number of nodes that the applications are currently deployed on in the cluster. The computation rounds up to tolerate one failure on small numbers of nodes. Default percentage: zero.

summary.para: Gets or sets the health policy used by default to evaluate the health of a service type.

value.para: The used to evaluate service type health if no service type policy is defined.

summary.para: Gets or sets the map with per service type name.

value.para: The map with service type health policy per service type name.

remarks.para: The entries in the map replace the default service type health policy for each specified service type. For example, in an application that contains both a stateless gateway service type and a stateful engine service type, the health policies for the stateless and stateful services can be configured differently. With policy per service type, there's more granular control of the health of the service.
If no policy is specified for a service type name, the is used for evaluation.

member.name: T:System.Fabric.Health.ApplicationHealthStateFilter
member.summary: Filter for objects.
member.remarks: The entity health state chunk queries can specify a list of application filters to fine-grain select the applications that should be included in the query result. Note that all the applications are used to evaluate cluster aggregated health state, regardless of the filter passed in.

member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.

member.name: P:System.Fabric.Health.ApplicationHealthStateFilter.HealthStateFilter
member.summary: Gets or sets filter for the aggregated health state of the entries in the collection.
member.value: The filter for the aggregated health state of the entries in the collection.
member.remarks: The health state filter value comes from members or bitwise combination of members of . For an application to match the filter, its aggregated health state must match the specified health state filter. If the health state filter is Default, the health state filter defaults to None if there are no specific filters (application name or application type name). Otherwise, the Default filter is considered to apply to All.

member.name: P:System.Fabric.Health.ApplicationHealthStateFilter.ApplicationNameFilter
member.summary: Gets or sets the application name filter.
member.value: The application name filter.
member.remarks: If specified, the filter applies only to the desired application. For the application to match the filter, its aggregated health state must match the specified health state filter.

summary.para: Initializes a new instance of the class.

member.remarks: By default, no errors or warnings are tolerated.

member.summary: Gets a string representation of the cluster health policy.
member.returns: A string representation of the cluster health policy.

summary.para: Gets or sets a that determines whether reports with warning state should be treated with the same severity as errors.

value.para: true if reports with warning state should be treated as errors; false if warnings should not be treated as errors.

summary.para: Gets or sets the maximum allowed percentage of unhealthy nodes.

value.para: The maximum allowed percentage of unhealthy nodes. Allowed values are integer values from zero to 100.

exception.para: The specified value was outside the range of integer values from zero to 100.

remarks.para: The percentage represents the maximum tolerated percentage of nodes that can be unhealthy before the cluster is considered in error. If the percentage is respected but there is at least one unhealthy node, the health is evaluated as Warning. This is calculated by dividing the number of unhealthy nodes over the total number of nodes in the cluster. The computation rounds up to tolerate one failure on small numbers of nodes. Default percentage: zero.
In large clusters, some nodes will always be down or out for repairs, so this percentage should be configured to tolerate that.

summary.para: Gets or sets the maximum allowed percentage of unhealthy applications.

value.para: The maximum allowed percentage of unhealthy applications. Allowed values are integer values from zero to 100.

exception.para: The specified value was outside the range of integer values from zero to 100.

remarks.para: The percentage represents the maximum tolerated percentage of applications that can be unhealthy before the cluster is considered in error. If the percentage is respected but there is at least one unhealthy application, the health is evaluated as Warning. This is calculated by dividing the number of unhealthy applications over the total number of applications deployed in the cluster, excluding all applications of an application types that are included in the . The computation rounds up to tolerate one failure on small numbers of applications. Default percentage: zero.

member.name: P:System.Fabric.Health.ClusterHealthPolicy.ApplicationTypeHealthPolicyMap

summary.para: Gets the map with MaxPercentUnhealthyApplications per application type name.

value.para: The application type health policy map with MaxPercentUnhealthyApplications per application type name.

member.remarks:
The application type health policy map can be used during cluster health evaluation to describe special application types. By default, all applications are put into a pool and evaluated with . If one or more application types are special and should be treated in a different way, they can be taken out of the global pool and evaluated against the percentages associated with their application type name in the map. For example, in a cluster there are thousands of applications of different types, and a few control application instances of a special application type. The control applications should never be in error. So users can specify global MaxPercentUnhealthyApplications to 20% to tolerate some failures, but for the application type "ControlApplicationType" set the MaxPercentUnhealthyApplications to 0. This way, if some of the many applications are unhealthy, but below the global unhealthy percentage, the cluster would be evaluated to Warning. A warning health state does not impact cluster upgrade or other monitoring triggered by Error health state. But even one control application in error would make cluster health error, which can rollback or prevent a cluster upgrade. >
For the application types defined in the map, all application instances are taken out of the global pool of applications. They are evaluated based on the total number of applications of the application type, using the specific MaxPercentUnhealthyApplications from the map. All the rest of the applications remain in the global pool and are evaluated with MaxPercentUnhealthyApplications.
To define entries for the specific application types in the cluster manifest, inside FabricSettings add entries for parameters with name formed by prefix "ApplicationTypeMaxPercentUnhealthyApplications-" followed by application type name.
If no policy is specified for an application type, the default MaxPercentUnhealthyApplications is used for evaluation.
The application type health evaluation is done only when the cluster is configured with EnableApplicationTypeHealthEvaluation true. The setting is disabled by default.

Creates a cluster health report.

param.para: The health information which describes the report parameters. Cannot be null.

summary.para: Defines a health policy used to evaluate the health of the cluster specific to cluster upgrade.

remarks.para: It’s used together with to evaluate cluster health and determine whether the monitored cluster upgrade is successful or needs to be rolled back.

summary.para: Initializes a new instance of the class.

member.name: P:System.Fabric.Health.ClusterUpgradeHealthPolicy.MaxPercentDeltaUnhealthyNodes

summary.para: Gets or sets the maximum allowed percentage of nodes health degradation allowed during cluster upgrades.

value.para: The maximum allowed percentage of delta health degradation. Allowed values are integer values from zero to 100.

member.remarks: The delta is measured between the state of the nodes at the beginning of upgrade and the state of the nodes at the time of the health evaluation. The check is performed after every upgrade domain upgrade completion to make sure the global state of the cluster is within tolerated limits. The default value is 10%.

exception.para: The specified value was outside the range of integer values from zero to 100.

member.name: P:System.Fabric.Health.ClusterUpgradeHealthPolicy.MaxPercentUpgradeDomainDeltaUnhealthyNodes

summary.para: Gets or sets the maximum allowed percentage of upgrade domain nodes health degradation allowed during cluster upgrades.

value.para: The maximum allowed percentage of upgrade domain delta health degradation. Allowed values are integer values from zero to 100.

member.remarks: The delta is measured between the state of the upgrade domain nodes at the beginning of upgrade and the state of the upgrade domain nodes at the time of the health evaluation. The check is performed after every upgrade domain upgrade completion for all completed upgrade domains to make sure the state of the upgrade domains is within tolerated limits. The default value is 15%.

exception.para: The specified value was outside the range of integer values from zero to 100.

summary.para: Gets the date and time when the health report was sent by the source.

value.para: The date and time when the health report was sent by the source.

summary.para: Gets the date and time when the health report was last modified by the health store.

value.para: The date and time when the health report was last modified by the health store.

summary.para: Gets a value that indicates whether the health event has expired.

value.para: true if the health event has expired; false if the health event was not expired at the time the health store evaluated the query.

remarks.para: An event can be expired only if RemoveWhenExpired is false. Otherwise, the event is not returned by query and is removed from the store.

summary.para: If the current is , returns the time at which the health report was first reported with . For periodic reporting, many reports with the same state may have been generated.

If the current is or , returns the time at which the health state was last in , before transitioning to a different state. If the has never been , the value will be System.DateTime.FromFileTimeUtc(0).

value.para: Returns representing the last transition time (UTC) involving .

remarks.para:
The transition fields, , , give the history of the health state transitions for the event. They can be used for smarter alerts or "historical" health event information. They enable scenarios such as:
Alert when a property has been at warning/error for more than X minutes. This avoids alerts on temporary conditions. For example, an alert if the health state has been warning for more than five minutes can be translated into (HealthState == Warning and Now - LastWarningTransitionTime > 5 minutes).
Alert only on conditions that have changed in the last X minutes. If a report was already at error before the specified time, it can be ignored because it was already signaled previously.
If a property is toggling between warning and error, determine how long it has been unhealthy (i.e. not OK). For example, an alert if the property hasn't been healthy for more than five minutes can be translated into (HealthState != Ok and Now - LastOkTransitionTime > 5 minutes).

summary.para: Represents common health report information. It is included in all health reports sent to health store and in all health events returned by health queries.

member.name: F:System.Fabric.Health.HealthInformation.UnknownSequenceNumber
member.summary: Unknown sequence number, which is an invalid sequence number that is not accepted by the health store.

member.name: F:System.Fabric.Health.HealthInformation.AutoSequenceNumber
member.summary: Auto sequence number, replaced with a valid sequence number by the health client.
member.remarks: When a health client receives a report with Auto sequence number, it replaces the auto sequence number with a valid sequence number. The sequence number is guaranteed to increase in the same process, even if the client machine time goes backwards.

summary.para: Initializes a new instance of the class.

param.name: sourceId
param.para: The source of the report. Cannot be null or empty. It can't start with "System.", which is reserved keyword for system components reporting.

param.name: property
param.para: The property of the report. Cannot be null or empty.

param.name: healthState
param.para: The health state of the report. Must be specified. Must be one of the , or values.

exception.para: cannot be null.
cannot be null.
cannot be empty.
cannot be empty.
Specified is not supported.

member.name: M:System.Fabric.Health.HealthInformation.ToString
member.summary: Creates a string description of the health information.
member.returns: String description of the health information.

summary.para: Gets the source Identifier which identifies the watchdog/system component which generated the health information.

value.para: A representing the source of the health report.

summary.para: Gets the property of the health report.

value.para: A representing the property of the health report. Together with the , it uniquely identifies the health information.

remarks.para: The property is a and not a fixed enumeration to allow the reporter to categorize the health event for a specific property of the entity. For example, reporter A can report the health of the Node01 "storage" property and reporter B can report the health of the Node01 "connectivity" property. In the health store, these reports are treated as separate health events for the Node01 entity.

summary.para: Gets the health state of the health information.

value.para: A representing the reported health state.

remarks.para: The accepted health states are , and .

summary.para: Gets or sets the description of the health information. It represents free text used to add human readable information about the report.

value.para: A which describes the health information in human readable form.

remarks.para: The maximum string length for the description is 4096 characters.

summary.para: Gets or sets how long the health report is valid. Must be larger than TimeSpan.Zero.

value.para: A representing the time to live of the health report.

remarks.para: When clients report periodically, they should send reports with higher frequency than time to live. If clients report on transition, they can set the time to live to infinite.
When time to live expires, the health event that contains the health information is either removed from health store, if is true or evaluated at error, if is false.

exception.para: The specified value was invalid. Please provide a duration that is larger than 0.

summary.para: Gets or sets a value that indicates whether the report is removed from health store when it expires. If set to false, the report is treated as an error when expired. false by default.

value.para: true if the report should be removed from health store when expired; otherwise, false.

remarks.para: When clients report periodically, they should set false (default). This way, is the reporter has issues (eg. deadlock) and can't report, the entity is evaluated at error when the health report expires, and this will flag the entity as . Periodic health clients should send reports with higher frequency than time to live to account for delays due to health client batching, message transport over the wire and health store processing.

summary.para: Gets or sets the sequence number associated with the report. Must be greater than .

value.para: An representing the report sequence number.

remarks.para: The report sequence number is used by health store to detect stale reports.

Most of the times, the reporter doesn't need to specify the sequence number. The default value can be used instead. When a health client receives a report with Auto sequence number, it replaces the auto sequence number with a valid sequence number. The sequence number is guaranteed to increase in the same process, even if the client machine time goes backwards.

summary.para: Represents the health report kind.
Indicates that the health report kind is invalid.

Indicates that the health report is for a service.

Indicates that the health report is for a deployed application.

Indicates that the health report is for cluster.
Represents the health state.
Indicates that the health state is invalid.
Indicates that the health state is ok.
Indicates that the health state is warning. There may something wrong that requires investigation.
Indicates that the health state is error, there is something wrong that needs to be investigated.
Indicates that the health state is unknown.

member.remarks: The health state filter value comes from members or bitwise combination of members of . For a partition to match the filter, its aggregated health state must match the specified health state filter.

member.name: P:System.Fabric.Health.PartitionHealthStateFilter.PartitionIdFilter
member.summary: Gets or sets the partition id filter.
member.value: The partition id filter.
member.remarks: If not specified, all partitions that match the parent filters (if any) and the specified health state filter match the filter. Otherwise, the filter only applies to the partition identified by the partition id. All the other filter members, like health state filter and replicas filter, are applied to this partition.

summary.para: Gets or sets the maximum allowed percentage of unhealthy services.

value.para: Returns the maximum allowed percentage of unhealthy services. Allowed values are values from zero to 100.

exception.para: The specified value was outside the range of integer values from zero to 100.

remarks.para: The percentage represents the maximum tolerated percentage of services that can be unhealthy before the application is considered in error. If the percentage is respected but there is at least one unhealthy service, the health is evaluated as Warning. This is calculated by dividing the number of unhealthy services of the specific service type over the total number of services of the specific service type. The computation rounds up to tolerate one failure on small numbers of services. Default percentage: zero.

summary.para: Gets or sets the maximum allowed percentage of unhealthy partitions per service.

value.para: Returns the maximum allowed percentage of unhealthy partitions per service. Allowed values are values from zero to 100.

exception.para: The specified value was outside the range of integer values from zero to 100.

remarks.para: The percentage represents the maximum tolerated percentage of partitions that can be unhealthy before the service is considered in error. If the percentage is respected but there is at least one unhealthy partition, the health is evaluated as Warning. This is calculated by dividing the number of unhealthy partitions over the total number of partitions in the service. The computation rounds up to tolerate one failure on small numbers of partitions. Default percentage: zero.

summary.para: Gets or sets the maximum allowed percentage of unhealthy replicas per partition.

value.para: Returns the maximum allowed percentage of unhealthy replicas per partition. Allowed values are values from zero to 100.

exception.para: The specified value was outside the range of integer values from zero to 100.

remarks.para: The percentage represents the maximum tolerated percentage of replicas that can be unhealthy before the partition is considered in error. If the percentage is respected but there is at least one unhealthy replica, the health is evaluated as Warning. This is calculated by dividing the number of unhealthy replicas over the total number of replicas in the partition. The computation rounds up to tolerate one failure on small numbers of replicas. Default percentage: zero.

summary.para: Describes additional methods of the interface that a user service must implement to take advantage of the atomic group functionality of a service group.
Defines the behavior that a service must implement to interact with the .
Obtains the last sequence number that the service has committed.

returns.para: Returns .

summary.para: Indicates to a replica that the configuration of a replica set has changed due to a change or attempted change to the Primary replica. The change occurs due to failure or load balancing of the previous Primary replica. Epoch changes act as a barrier by segmenting operations into the exact configuration periods in which they were sent by a specific Primary replica.

param.name: epoch
param.para: The new .

param.name: previousEpochLastSequenceNumber
param.para: The maximum sequence number (LSN) in the previous epoch.

param.name: cancellationToken
param.para: The object that the operation is observing. It can be used to send a notification that the operation should be canceled. Note that cancellation is advisory and that the operation might still be completed even if it is canceled.

returns.para: Returns .

remarks.para: The information in the method enables the service to maintain a progress vector, which is a list of each epoch that the replica has received, and the maximum LSN that they contained.
The progress vector data along with the current applied maximum LSN is useful for a Secondary replica to send during the copy operation to describe the state of the replica.

Comparing progress vectors that are received from Secondary replicas during the copy operation enables Primary replicas to determine whether the Secondary replica is up-to-date, what state must be sent to the Secondary replica, and whether the Secondary replica has made false progress.
False progress means that a secondary replica reports an LSN in a previous epoch was greater than the LSN that the Primary replica has in its progress vector.

summary.para: Indicates that a write quorum of replicas in this replica set has been lost, and that therefore data loss might have occurred. The replica set consists of a majority of replicas, which includes the Primary replica.

param.name: cancellationToken
param.para: The object that the operation is observing. It can be used to send a notification that the operation should be canceled. Note that cancellation is advisory and that the operation might still be completed even if it is canceled.

returns.para: Returns of type , that indicates whether the state provider as part of processing this notification has changed its state

remarks.para: When the Service Fabric runtime observes the failure of a quorum of replicas, which includes the Primary replica, it elects a new Primary replica and immediately calls this method on the new Primary replica. A Primary replica that is informed of possible data loss can choose to restore its state from some external data source or can continue to run with the state that it currently has. If the service continues to run with its current state, it should return false from this method, which indicates that no state change has been made. If it has restored or altered its state, such as rolling back incomplete work, it should return true. If true is returned, then the state in other replicas must be assumed to be incorrect. Therefore, the Service Fabric runtime removes the other replicas from the replica set and recreates them.

summary.para: Obtains context on a Secondary replica after it is created and opened to send context to the Primary replica.

returns.para: Returns .

remarks.para: The Primary replica analyzes the context and sends back state via .

is called on newly created, idle Secondary replicas and provides a mechanism to asynchronously establish a bidirectional conversation with the Primary replica. The Secondary replica sends objects with which the Primary replica can determine the progress of collecting context on the Secondary replica. The Primary replica responds by sending the required state back. See at the Primary replica for the other half of the exchange.
For in-memory services, the method is not called, as the state of the Secondary replicas is known (they are empty and will require all of the state).

summary.para: Obtains state on a Primary replica that is required to build a Secondary replica.

param.name: upToSequenceNumber
param.para: The maximum last sequence number (LSN) that should be placed in the copy stream via the method. LSNs greater than this number are delivered to the Secondary replica as a part of the replication stream via the method.

param.name: copyContext
param.para: An that contains the objects that are created by the Secondary replica.

returns.para: Returns .

remarks.para: Just as enables the Secondary replica to send context to the Primary replica via an , enables the Primary replica to respond with an . The stream contains objects that are delivered to the Secondary replica via the method of the class. The objects implement and contain the specified data.

When the Primary replica receives this call, it should create and return another that contains . represents the data/state that the Secondary replica requires to catch up to the provided maximum LSN. How much and which state has to be sent can be determined via the context information that the Secondary replica provides via method.

summary.para: Acknowledges that this operation has been successfully applied at the Secondary replica.

remarks.para: Services should call this method when they have obtained an from the replicator and successfully applied it to their local store. For persisted services, calling this method is mandatory because the does not release additional objects that implement . For volatile services, the replicator implicitly acknowledges operations when they are received unless they are configured otherwise by setting the value to true. An operation must be acknowledged by a quorum of replicas before the Primary replica receives the operation complete responses.

remarks.para: The new role is indicated as a parameter. When the service transitions to the new role, the service has a chance to update its current listening address. The listening address is the address where clients connect to it. This enables the service when it is a Primary replica to only claim some resources such as ports when communication from clients is expected.

summary.para: Closes the replica and its replicator in preparation for going offline from a replica set.

param.name: cancellationToken
param.para: Currently unused. Reserved for future use.

returns.para: A task that represents the asynchronous operation.

remarks.para: The replica has not necessarily been removed permanently from the replica set and may be re-opened at a later time. The most common causes for closing a replica is graceful shutdown in preparation for upgrade or load balancing. This method does not need to be called explicitly if the application replica derives from , which is the recommended pattern. In this case, the application replica should override instead.

member.name: M:System.Fabric.KeyValueStoreReplica.BackupAsync(System.String,System.Fabric.StoreBackupOption,System.Func{System.Fabric.StoreBackupInfo,System.Threading.Tasks.Task{System.Boolean}})

summary.para: Asynchronously creates a backup of the key-value store.

member.param: The directory where the backup is to be stored. If backupOption is , then this parameter should be null. Otherwise, this parameter cannot be null, empty or contain just whitespace. UNC paths may also be provided. If the directory doesn't exist, it is created. If it exists and isn't empty, then incremental backup fails with .

param.name: backupOption
param.para: The options for the backup.

member.param: The post backup asynchronous method that is invoked by Windows Fabric to allow the user to complete any post backup activity before returning control to the system. If null is passed in for this, incremental backups are disallowed. If the post-backup method returns false, then again, incremental backups are disallowed.
member.returns: A task that represents the asynchronous backup operation.
member.exception: backupDirectory is null when backupOption is not .
backupDirectory is empty or contains just whitespaces when backupOption is not or backupDirectory is not null when backupOption is .
When backupOption is and the backup directory already contains files or sub-directories.
When a previously initiated backup is currently in progress.
member.remarks: The postBackupAsyncFunc is not invoked if there is an error during backup. Also, it is not invoked when backupOption is since there is no further action needed from the user in this case to complete a single backup cycle.

summary.para: Restores this replica’s local store database from a backup that was previously created by calling Backup.

param.name: backupDirectory
param.para: The full path to a backup created by previously calling Backup.

remarks.para: This is only a local replica restore and the replica set is not automatically restored. The entire replica set must be restored by taking additional steps to cause a natural build of other replicas via reconfiguration. The recommended approach is to restore to an empty service with only a single replica and increase the target replica set size afterwards with a call to UpdateService if needed.

If the restore is successful, then the replica will restart itself and start using the restored local data after coming back online given that the recommendation to restore to a replica set containing only a single replica was followed.

member.name: M:System.Fabric.KeyValueStoreReplica.RestoreAsync(System.String)

summary.para: Restores this replica’s local store database from a backup that was previously created by calling Backup

member.param: The directory where the replica is to be restored from. This parameter cannot be null, empty or contain just whitespace. UNC paths may also be provided.
member.returns: A task that represents the asynchronous restore operation.
member.exception: backupDirectory is null.
backupDirectory is empty or contains just whitespaces.
backupDirectory does not exist.

remarks.para: It is recommended to not perform any write operations to the key-value store while restore is underway since the updated data would be lost when the store is restored from the files in backupDirectory.

summary.para: Indicates that this replica is changing roles.

param.name: newRole
param.para: The target role.

param.name: cancellationToken
param.para: Currently unused. Reserved for future use.

returns.para: A task whose result is the resolvable address of this replica..

remarks.para: The application replica should override this method if deriving from , which is the recommended pattern. The application replica should return a Task whose result is the address of this replica. This replica address is stored by the system as is and can be retrieved (unmodified) using ResolveServiceAsync. The application must take care to complete the role change in a timely manner since reconfiguration of the replica set will be blocked behind the completion of all outstanding change role calls.

summary.para: Called to shut down this instance.
Called by the system on secondary replicas when they have finished building from the primary and are ready to start applying replication operations.
This method will only be called on secondary replicas if the object was constructed with a parameter.

param.name: enumerator
param.para: The enumerator used to read data on the secondary.

remarks.para: The object can be used to read data on the secondary within the context of this method before any replication operations are applied. The object is no longer valid after this method returns and cannot be used outside the context of this method. The application must take care to complete this callback in a timely manner since replication operations are being queued on the secondary replica and will not start getting applied until this method returns. The object is backed by a single underlying local transaction and is not thread-safe.

summary.para: Called by the system on secondary replicas for incoming replication operations. Each object contains all the data for a single atomic replication operation.

param.name: enumerator
param.para: The enumerator used to read the data in this replication operation.

remarks.para: This method will only be called on secondary replicas if the object was constructed with a valid .

If the BlockSecondaryAck mode was specified, then the incoming replication operation is not applied locally on the secondary replica and acknowledged to the primary until the method returns. This implies that the application must take care to return from this method in a timely manner to avoiding blocking the replication stream. Since the acknowledgment is not sent to the primary until this method returns, it cannot be assumed that the observed replication operation has already been (or is guaranteed to be in the future) applied by a quorum of replicas in the replica set.

If the NonBlockingQuorumAcked mode was specified, then the observed replication operation is guaranteed to have already been applied by a quorum of replicas in the replica set. Furthermore, the observed replication operation may have already been applied locally by this secondary and acknowledged to the primary at the time the method is invoked by the system. The method callback will not block the replication stream in this mode, but it will still block the replication operation notification stream. That is, there will only be one outstanding OnReplicationOperation method callback at any given time.

summary.para: Describes the move cost of a replica.

member.remarks:
When a new replica or service instance is created it will get a default value for move cost. This value will be selected based on the service:
For replicas or instances of default services default move cost value will be , meaning that moving these replicas is free.
For replicas or instances of other services default move cost will be .

summary.para: Describes the reason why the node is being deactivated.

remarks.para: The enumeration is provided as a part of the method.
Service Fabric uses this information to take the correct actions at the node to provide a graceful shutdown of the node. The intents have a general progression or severity.
A deactivation that is started with one intent can be increased to subsequent higher levels of intent. The general order of this progression is: Pause, Restart, Stop, ForceStop.

summary.para: Indicates that a deactivation intent is invalid. This value is not used.
Indicates that the node should be paused.

remarks.para: When this intent is used, Service Fabric prevents changes to the specified node. No new replicas are placed on the node, and existing replicas are not moved or shut down.
The intent is useful when one or more replicas on a node encounter issues and that node has to be isolated for further investigation
This investigation could include accessing the remote machine to investigate such activities as reviewing local logs, taking memory dumps, and observing other information.
The purpose of this mode is to attempt to preserve the node so that additional debugging can be performed under the same conditions that existed when the error occurred.
Note that specifying this mode does not guarantee that all changes to the node can be prevented.
For example, replicas on the node might crash after the intent to pause the node has been received.
As another example, failures in another location in the cluster might cause a Secondary replica on the node to be promoted to the Primary replica.
In this mode, Service Fabric will disable Placement and Resource Balancing on the target node
In addition Safety Checks (see ) will be performed by Service Fabric

summary.para: Indicates that the intent is for the node to be restarted after a short period of time. Service Fabric does not restart the node - this action is done outside of Service Fabric.

remarks.para: A node might be shut down, for example, to perform an OS update or a Service Fabric code update.
In this mode, Service Fabric prevents new replicas from being placed on the node. Additionally, Service Fabric takes the following actions:
Disable Placement and Resource balancing on the target node
Performs safety checks. The safety check is not performed for this intent.
Close all replicas and instances running on the node.
NOTE: Once replicas and instances are closed, Service Fabric will reactively create replacements for replicas of stateful volatile services and stateless services.

For Persisted replicas on the node, new replicas are not be built, because the intention is to restart this node and to recover the persistent state after the restart. The replicas are opened once the node is activated.

summary.para: Indicates that the intent is to reimage the node. Service Fabric does not reimage the node - this action is done outside of Service Fabric.

remarks.para: When Service Fabric receives this intent, it ensures that:
In this mode, Service Fabric prevents new replicas from being placed on the node. Additionally, Service Fabric takes the following actions:
Disable Placement and Resource balancing on the target node
Move all Up replicas out of the node.
For stateless instances this implies creating another instance on another node
For replicas of stateful services a replacement replica is built on another node (if there is sufficient capacity in the cluster)
If the replica is a primary, some other active secondary of the partition is made the primary prior to creating the replacement
Stateful replicas on the node receive notifications to clean up their state and close.
Performs a subset of safety checks that ensure that as a result of taking this node down no data loss can occur.

summary.para: Indicates that the node is being decommissioned and is not expected to return. Service Fabric does not decommission the node - this action is done outside of Service Fabric.

remarks.para: When Service Fabric receives this intent, it ensures that:
In this mode, Service Fabric prevents new replicas from being placed on the node. Additionally, Service Fabric takes the following actions:
Disable Placement and Resource balancing on the target node
Move all Up replicas out of the node.
For stateless instances this implies creating another instance on another node
For replicas of stateful services a replacement replica is built on another node (if there is sufficient capacity in the cluster)
If the replica is a primary, some other active secondary of the partition is made the primary prior to creating the replacement
Stateful replicas on the node receive notifications to clean up their state and close.
Performs a subset of safety checks that ensure that as a result of taking this node down no data loss can occur.

Enumerates the access status of the partition.

remarks.para: is used to check that a read or write operation is allowed. When service replicas handle a client request, they should verify that the system is in a state that allows processing. By checking the or as appropriate, the replica can be notified of conditions that prevent correct operation. Note that write operations might still see an exception from the replicator for one of these conditions, because the condition might change between the check and the call to .

summary.para: Indicates that the read or write operation access status is not valid. This value is not returned to the caller.
Indicates that the read or write operation access is granted and the operation is allowed.

Indicates that the client should try again later, because a reconfiguration is in progress. After the reconfiguration is completed, a new status is returned that gives further instructions. The client should retry the operation at this replica

Indicates that this client request was received by a replica that is not a Primary replica. The read or write operation cannot be performed at this replica. The client should attempt to use the naming service to identify the correct primary replica.
Indicates that no write quorum is available and, therefore, no write operation can be accepted. The client should retry the operation at this replica.

member.summary: Gets or sets the name of the application.
member.value: The name of the application.

member.name: P:System.Fabric.Query.ApplicationLoadInformation.MinimumNodes
member.summary: Gets the minimum number of nodes for this application.

value.para: Number of nodes where Service Fabric will reserve Capacity in the cluster for this Application instance. This value is equal to that was set when the application was created or updated.

member.name: P:System.Fabric.Query.ApplicationLoadInformation.MaximumNodes
member.summary: Gets the maximum number of nodes where this application can be instantiated.

value.para: Number of nodes this application is allowed to span. This value is equal to that was set when application was created or updated.

member.remarks: For applications that do not have application capacity defined this value will be zero.

member.name: P:System.Fabric.Query.ApplicationLoadInformation.NodeCount
member.summary: Gets the number of nodes on which this application is instantiated.

value.para: The number of nodes on which this application is currently instantiated.

member.remarks: For applications that do not have application capacity defined this value will be zero.

member.name: P:System.Fabric.Query.ApplicationLoadInformation.ApplicationLoadMetricInformation
member.summary: Gets the list of loads per metric for this application instance.
member.value: The list of loads per metric for for this application instance. For each metric that was defined in when application was created or updated there will be one instance of in this list.
member.remarks: For applications that do not have application capacity defined this list will be empty.

summary.para: Contains the detailed deactivation information about a node.

A node may get deactivated by multiple tasks at the same time. Each task may specify a different node deactivation intent. In this case, effective intent is highest intent among all deactivation tasks, where ordering is defined as Pause < Restart < RemoveData.

summary.para: Represents the operation currently being executed by the Replicator, either via or interface.
Default value if the replicator is not yet ready.
Replicator is not running any operation from Service Fabric perspective.
Replicator is opening.
Replicator is in the process of changing its role.
Due to a change in the replica set, replicator is being updated with its Epoch.
Replicator is closing.
Replicator is being aborted.
Replicator is handling the data loss condition, where the user service may potentially be recovering state from an external source.
Replicator is waiting for a quorum of replicas to be caught up to the latest state.
Replicator is in the process of building one or more replicas.

Gets the replica ID of the secondary.

remarks.para: UTC 0 represents an invalid value, indicating that no acknowledgement messages were ever processed.

summary.para: Gets the highest copy operation sequence number that the secondary has applied to its state.

remarks.para: A value of ‘-1’ can be ignored since it indicates that the copy process is complete.

summary.para: Provides various statistics of the queue used in the Service Fabric Replicator.

remarks.para: Depending on the role of the replicator ( or ), the properties in this type mean different things.

Gets the utilization of the queue.

remarks.para: A value of ‘0’ indicates that the queue is empty and a value of ‘100’ indicates that the queue is full.

summary.para: See remarks.

value.para: The first sequence number.

description.para: – Represents the smallest sequence number of the operation that is present in the queue. It’s value will be the same as , since the primary replicator discards operations once it receives an acknowledgement from all the secondary replicas.
– Represents the sequence number of the first operation that is available in the queue.

summary.para: See remarks.

value.para: The completed sequence number.

description.para: – Represents the highest sequence number for which all the secondary replicas have applied the operation.
– Represents the highest sequence number that has been applied by the user service replica.

summary.para: See remarks.

value.para: The committed sequence number.

description.para: – Represents the highest sequence number for which a quorum of secondary replicas have applied the operation.
– Represents the highest sequence number that has been received by the secondary replicator from the primary.

summary.para: See remarks.

value.para: The last sequence number.

description.para: – Represents the latest sequence number of the operation that is available in the queue.
– Represents the latest sequence number of the operation that is available in the queue.

summary.para: Represents a repair task that has Cluster scope.
This class supports the Service Fabric platform; it is not meant to be called directly from your code.
Represents a repair task, which includes information about what kind of repair was requested, what its progress is, and what its final result was.
This class supports the Service Fabric platform; it is not meant to be called directly from your code.
Gets an object describing the scope of the repair task.

value.para: A object describing the scope of the repair task.

remarks.para: The repair task scope determines the resource against which access checks are performed when the repair task is created, modified, deleted, or retrieved. Entities impacted by a repair must be contained within the scope of the repair task. For example, repairs which impact nodes require that the repair task be created under the Cluster scope.

summary.para: Gets the identifier of the repair task.

value.para: The identifier of the repair task.

summary.para: Gets or sets the version of the repair task.

value.para: The version of the repair task.

remarks.para: When creating a new repair task, the version must be set to zero. When updating a repair task via the UpdateRepairExecutionStateAsync method, the version is used for optimistic concurrency checks. If the version is set to zero, the update will not check for write conflicts. If the version is set to a non-zero value, then the update will only succeed if the actual current version of the repair task matches this value.

summary.para: Gets an object that describes the impact of the repair.

remarks.para: Impact must be specified by the repair executor upon transitioning to the Preparing state. The impact object determines what actions the system will take to prepare for the impact of the repair, prior to approving execution of the repair.

This type supports the Service Fabric platform; it is not meant to be used directly from your code.
Indicates that the repair task result is invalid.
Indicates that the repair task completed execution successfully.
Indicates that the repair task was cancelled prior to execution.
Indicates that execution of the repair task was interrupted by a cancellation request after some work had already been performed.
Indicates that there was a failure during execution of the repair task. Some work may have been performed.

This type supports the Service Fabric platform; it is not meant to be used directly from your code.
Indicates that the repair task state is invalid.
Indicates that the repair task has been created.

Indicates that the Repair Manager is preparing the system to handle the impact of the repair task, usually by taking resources offline gracefully.
Indicates that the repair task has been approved by the Repair Manager and is safe to execute.
Indicates that execution of the repair task is in progress.
Indicates that the Repair Manager is restoring the system to its pre-repair state, usually by bringing resources back online.
Indicates that the repair task has completed, and no further state changes will occur.
Specifies values that can be combined as a bitmask to retrieve repair tasks filtered by their current workflow state.
Includes all repair tasks, regardless of state.
Includes repair tasks in the Created state.
Includes repair tasks in the Claimed state.
Includes repair tasks in the Preparing state.
Includes repair tasks in the Approved state.
Includes repair tasks in the Executing state.
Includes repair tasks in the Restoring state.
Includes repair tasks in the Completed state.
Includes repair tasks in the Approved or Executing state.
Includes repair tasks that are not completed.
Includes all repair tasks, regardless of state.
Specifies node repair actions for which the system has a built-in executor.

Reboots the OS of the target nodes.
Reimages the OS volume of the target nodes.
Reimages all disk volumes of the target nodes, destroying all data stored on the nodes.

summary.para: Indicates the role of a stateful service replica.

remarks.para: Service Fabric requires different behaviors from a service replica depending on what role it currently performs.

summary.para: Indicates the initial role that a replica is created in.
Specifies that the replica has no responsibility in regard to the replica set.

remarks.para: When indicates this role, it is safe to delete any persistent state that is associated with this replica.

summary.para: Refers to the replica in the set on which all read and write operations are complete in order to enforce strong consistency semantics. Read operations are handled directly by the Primary replica, while write operations must be acknowledged by a quorum of the replicas in the replica set. There can only be one Primary replica in a replica set at a time.

Refers to a replica in the set that receives a state transfer from the Primary replica to prepare for becoming an active Secondary replica. There can be multiple Idle Secondary replicas in a replica set at a time. Idle Secondary replicas do not count as a part of a write quorum.

Refers to a replica in the set that receives state updates from the Primary replica, applies them, and sends acknowledgements back. Secondary replicas must participate in the write quorum for a replica set. There can be multiple active Secondary replicas in a replica set at a time. The number of active Secondary replicas is configurable that the reliability subsystem should maintain.

summary.para: Allows a stateful replica to configure the when creating it via .
Initializes a new instance of the class.
Loads the object from the service configuration settings file.

param.name: codePackageActivationContext
param.para: The current code package activation context

param.name: configPackageName
param.para: The current configuration package name

param.name: sectionName
param.para: The section within the configuration file that defines all the replicator settings

returns.para: The loaded object from the service configuration settings file

remarks.para: The configuration settings file (settings.xml) within the service configuration folder generally contains all the replicator settings that is needed to pass in the object to the method. Typically, the onus is on the service author to read the settings.xml file, parse the values and appropriately construct the object.
With the current helper method, the service author can bypass the above process.
The following are the parameter names that should be provided in the service configuration “settings.xml”, to be recognizable by windows fabric to perform the above parsing automatically:

description.para: BatchAcknowledgementInterval – value in seconds
InitialCopyQueueSize -
MaxCopyQueueSize -
MaxReplicationMessageSize -
RetryInterval - value in seconds
RequireServiceAck -
ReplicatorAddress or ReplicatorEndpoint – ReplicatorAddress should be of the form IPort. ReplicatorEndpoint must reference a valid service endpoint resource from the service manifest -
SecondaryClearAcknowledgedOperations -
PrimaryWaitForPendingQuorumsTimeout - value in seconds
UseStreamFaultsAndEndOfStreamOperationAck -
InitialPrimaryReplicationQueueSize -
InitialSecondaryReplicationQueueSize -
MaxPrimaryReplicationQueueSize -
MaxSecondaryReplicationQueueSize -
MaxPrimaryReplicationQueueMemorySize -
MaxSecondaryReplicationQueueMemorySize -

summary.para: Defines how long the waits after it transmits a message from the primary to the secondary for the secondary to acknowledge that it has received the message.

value.para: The time needed the waits after it transmits a message from the primary to the secondary for the secondary to acknowledge that it has received the message.

remarks.para: Receiving a message does not necessarily that the message has been processed.
If this timer is exceeded, then the message is retransmitted.
The default value is 5 seconds.

summary.para: Gets or sets the amount of time that the replicator waits after receiving an operation before sending back an acknowledgment.

value.para: The amount of time that the replicator waits after receiving an operation before sending back an acknowledgment.

remarks.para: Other operations received and acknowledged during this time period will have their acknowledgments sent back in a single message.
Increasing the value decreases latency of individual replication operations but increases throughput of the replicator.
Default value is 0.05 Seconds (50 milliseconds)

summary.para: Configures the address that this replicator will use when communicating with other Replicators.

value.para: The address that this replicator will use when communicating with other Replicators.

remarks.para: String is formatted as “hostname:port”, where hostname can be FQDN or IP address. The default value is localhost:0

summary.para: Allows the service to define security credentials for securing the traffic between replicators.

value.para: The service to define security credentials for securing the traffic between replicators.

summary.para: Gets or sets the initial size of the replication queue size.

value.para: The initial size of the replication queue size.

summary.para: Gets or sets the maximum size for the replication queue.

value.para: the maximum size for the replication queue.

summary.para: Gets or sets the initial size of the copy operation queue inside , which contains copy s not yet pumped and processed by the service.

value.para: The initial size of the copy operation queue inside , which contains copy s not yet pumped and processed by the service.

remarks.para: The default value is 64. Note that values for this parameter must be a power of 2.

summary.para: Gets or sets the maximum size of the copy operation queue inside , which contains copy s not yet pumped and processed by the service.

value.para: The maximum size of the copy operation queue inside , which contains copy s not yet pumped and processed by the service.

remarks.para: If this queue size is reached at the secondary, operations will be buffered in the Primary’s copy queue. If that queue also fills, then the Primary will begin seeing exceptions.
The default value is 1024

summary.para: Prevents the optimistic acknowledgment of operations in non-persistent services by requiring that the service calls before it pumps the next operation.

value.para: true if the optimistic acknowledgment of operations in non-persistent services;otherwise, false.

remarks.para: Non-persistent services which require explicit acknowledgment can set this property to True in order to prevent optimistic acknowledgment of the operations by the Replicator. This setting has no effect for persistent services.
The default value is false.

summary.para: Gets or sets the maximum size for the replication queue memory.

value.para: The maximum size for the replication queue memory.

remarks.para: The default value is 0. This implies there is no memory limit

summary.para: Typically, operations in the secondary replicator are kept in the queue to be able to catchup replicas if it is promoted to a primary. With this flag enabled, the secondary replicator releases the operation as soon as it is acknowledged by the user service.

value.para: true if the secondary replicator releases the operation as soon as it is acknowledged by the user service; otherwise, false.

remarks.para: The default value is false

summary.para: Gets or sets the maximum size of a message that can be transmitted via the replicator. These include replication messages, copy messages and copy context messages. The unit of representation is bytes.

value.para: The maximum size of a message that can be transmitted via the replicator.

remarks.para: The default value is 50MB

summary.para: Defines the initial size of the primary replication operation queue inside , which contains replication s.The unit here is the number of operations in the queue.

value.para: The initial size of the primary replication operation queue inside

remarks.para: This setting is specific to the Replicator when the role of the service is Primary
The default value is 64. Note that values for this parameter must be a power of 2.

summary.para: Defines the maximum size of the primary replication operation queue inside , which contains replication s

value.para: The maximum size of the primary replication operation queue inside , which contains replication s. The unit here is the number of operations in the queue.

remarks.para: If this queue size is reached, then the Primary will begin seeing exceptions.
The default value is 1024 Note that values for this parameter must be a power of 2.
This setting is specific to the Replicator when the role of the service is Primary

summary.para: Defines the maximum size of the primary replication operation queue inside , which contains replication s

value.para: . Returns the maximum size of the primary replication operation queue inside , which contains replication s The unit here is the virtual memory consumption of the queue .Returns .

remarks.para: This setting is specific to the Replicator when the role of the service is Primary. The default value is 0. This implies there is no memory limit

summary.para: Defines the initial size of the secondary replication operation queue inside , which contains replication s

value.para: The initial size of the secondary replication operation queue inside , which contains replication s not yet pumped and processed by the service. The unit here is the number of operations in the queue

remarks.para: This setting is specific to the Replicator when the role of the service is Secondary/Idle
The default value is 64. Note that values for this parameter must be a power of 2.

summary.para: Defines the maximum size of the secondary replication operation queue inside , which contains replication s

value.para: The maximum size of the secondary replication operation queue inside , which contains replication s not yet pumped and processed by the service. The unit here is the number of operations in the queue

remarks.para: If this queue size is reached, operations will be buffered in the Primary’s replication queue. If that queue also fills, then the Primary will begin seeing exceptions.
The default value is 2048.Note that values for this parameter must be a power of 2.
This setting is specific to the Replicator when the role of the service is Secondary/Idle

summary.para: Defines the maximum size of the secondary replication operation queue inside , which contains replication s.

value.para: Returns the maximum size of the secondary replication operation queue inside , which contains replication s. The unit here is the virtual memory consumption of the queue.

remarks.para: This setting is specific to the Replicator when the role of the service is Secondary/Idle. The default value is 0. This implies there is no memory limit

summary.para: Defines how long the primary replicator waits for receiving a quorum of acknowledgments for any pending replication operations before processing a reconfiguration request, that could potentially result in ‘cancelling’ the pending replication operations.

value.para: Amount of time the primary replicator waits for receiving a quorum of acknowledgments for any pending replication operations when there is a request for the primary replicator to process a reconfiguration .

remarks.para: The default value is 0. This implies that reconfigurations aren’t waited upon for receiving quorum on the pending replication operations. This helps in completing reconfigurations sooner. Note that larger values for this parameter could potentially result in slower reconfigurations, implying longer durations to fail-over a primary.

summary.para: Represents a resolved service endpoint.
Gets the role of a service endpoint.

value.para: The role of a service endpoint.

remarks.para: Endpoint roles are used by a client to select which service instance or replica to select and connect to.

summary.para: Gets the address for the endpoint. The string is given to Service Fabric to be broadcast by the service.

value.para: The address for the endpoint.

summary.para: Represents a data structure that contains information on the partitioning and set of endpoints to which the specified Service partition listens.
Returns a single endpoint, instead of a collection of all endpoints.

returns.para: Returns .

remarks.para: Many times, you only need a single endpoint instead of all the endpoints. If the service is stateless, it returns a random endpoint. If the service is a stateful service, than it returns the endpoint to which the Primary replica of the service partition listens. Note that if the Primary replica currently does not exist, it throws .

summary.para: Compares two resolved service partitions and identifies which is newer.

param.name: other
param.para: The other resolved service partition to compare.

returns.para: Returns .

exception.para: The two objects are from different service partitions. This can happen if the service is deleted and re-created with the same name and partitioning between two resolve calls.

remarks.para: The method takes in a resolved service partition (RSP) argument with the parameter to enable the user to identify which RSP is more up-to-date. A returned value of 0 indicates that the two RSPs have the same version. 1 indicates that the other RSP has an older version. -1 indicates that the other RSP has a newer version.

summary.para: Gets the endpoints of the service partition.

value.para: A collection of for a service partition.

member.value: The information about the partition of the service that was resolved.

summary.para: Gets the name of the service instance.

value.para: Returns .

summary.para: Specifies the type of rolling upgrade when upgrading an application instance or cluster.

remarks.para: For more information, see Upgrade and Scale a Service Fabric Cluster and Upgrade an Application.

summary.para: All Service Fabric enumerations have reserved Invalid flag.
Specifies that the upgrade should be unmonitored automatic.

remarks.para: Using this mode, automatically proceeds to upgrading the next upgrade domain until all upgrade domains are upgraded.

summary.para: Specifies that the upgrade should be unmonitored manual.

remarks.para: Using this mode, the administrator needs to instruct to move to the next upgrade domain (using the or methods) and continue the upgrade.

summary.para: Specifies that the upgrade should be monitored automatic.

remarks.para: After an upgrade domain (UD) is upgraded, Service Fabric will proceed to upgrade the next UD if the health of the UD and the cluster meets the defined health policies for that upgrade. Otherwise, the entire upgrade is marked as failed and the upgrade failure action is taken. The default failure action is to roll-back the entire upgrade.

member.name: T:System.Fabric.CompletionMode
member.summary: This is an enum used to indicate when the API should complete.
member.remarks: The values indicate whether the API should complete when the request for the operation is done or when the requested operation has completed. For example, a request to restart a node could complete as soon the request is accepted or when the API can verify that the node has restarted. The actual verification depends upon the API being used.

member.name: F:System.Fabric.CompletionMode.Invalid
member.summary: Completion mode does not have a valid value.

member.name: F:System.Fabric.CompletionMode.DoNotVerify
member.summary: Do not verify the completion of the action.

member.name: F:System.Fabric.CompletionMode.Verify
member.summary: Verify the completion of the action.

member.name: T:System.Fabric.DataLossMode
member.summary: This enum is passed to the DataLoss testability API to indicate what type of data loss to induce.

member.name: F:System.Fabric.DataLossMode.Invalid
member.summary: Reserved. Do not pass into API.

member.name: F:System.Fabric.DataLossMode.PartialDataLoss
member.summary: PartialDataLoss option will cause a quorum of replicas to go down, triggering an OnDataLoss event in the system for the given partition.
member.remarks: Whether actual data loss happens depends on whether there were committed transactions that were still being replicated at the time the data loss was induced

member.name: F:System.Fabric.DataLossMode.FullDataLoss
member.summary: FullDataLoss option will drop all the replicas which means that all the data will be lost.
member.remarks: This option is very useful to test out backup and recovery data paths.

member.name: T:System.Fabric.QuorumLossMode
member.summary: Type of QuorumLoss that will be invoked.

member.name: F:System.Fabric.QuorumLossMode.Invalid
member.summary: Reserved. Do not pass into API.

member.name: F:System.Fabric.QuorumLossMode.QuorumReplicas
member.summary: Partial Quorum loss mode : Minimum number of replicas for a partition will be down that will cause a quorum loss.

member.name: F:System.Fabric.QuorumLossMode.AllReplicas
member.summary: Full Quorum loss mode : All replicas for a partition will be down that will cause a quorum loss.

summary.para: Represents a transaction.
Provides an abstract base class for a transaction.
Enables an object to try to free resources and perform other cleanup operations before it is reclaimed by garbage collection.
Performs application-defined tasks that are associated with freeing, releasing, or resetting unmanaged resources.
The dispose event occurs when the transaction is disposed of through the OnDispose method.

remarks.para: When overriding , be sure to call the OnDispose method on the base class.

summary.para: Gets a value that indicates whether the object has been disposed.

returns.para: Returns true if the object has been disposed; otherwise, returns false.

summary.para: Gets the ID of the transaction as a .

value.para: The transaction ID as a .

summary.para: Gets the isolation level of the transaction as a .

value.para: A object that represents the isolation level of the transaction.

remarks.para: The isolation level of a transaction determines what level of access to volatile data other transactions have before a transaction finishes. For more information about isolation levels, see the documentation for the enumeration.

summary.para: Rolls back the set of operations that are associated with this transaction.
Commits the set of operations associated with the transaction. Replication and local disk writes are performed asynchronously

returns.para: A Task whose result is the Logical Sequence Number of the transaction..
