Enumerates the set of possible isolation levels for a .
Indicates the default isolation level of the store.
Indicates that volatile data can be read during the transaction.

Indicates that volatile data cannot be read during the transaction, but can be modified. Shared locks are held while data is being read to avoid dirty reads, but data can be changed before the end of the transaction that results in non-repeatable reads or phantom data.

Indicates that volatile data can be read but not modified during the transaction. Locks are placed on all data that is used in a query to prevent other users from updating data. New rows can be inserted into data sets and are included in later reads in the current transaction.
Indicates the snapshot level where volatile data can be read. Any data that is read will be a transaction-consistent version of the data that existed at start of the transaction.

Indicates that volatile data are serializable. Volatile data can be read but not modified, and no new data can be added during the transaction. Indicates that range locks will be put on data sets. The locks prevent updates or inserts in data sets until the transaction finishes.

summary.para: Enumerates the that is being performed for a node during upgrade.
Indicates that the upgrade safety check kind is invalid. This value is not used.
Indicates that if we bring down the node then this will result in global seed node quorum loss.
Indicates that there is some partition for which if we bring down the replica on the node, it will result in quorum loss for that partition.
Indicates that there is some replica on the node that was moved out of this node due to upgrade. Service Fabric is now waiting for the primary to be moved back to this node.
Indicates that Service Fabric is waiting for a primary replica to be moved out of the node before starting upgrade on that node.
Indicates that there is some replica on the node that is involved in a reconfiguration. Service Fabric is waiting for the reconfiguration to be complete before staring upgrade on that node.

Indicates that there is either a replica on the node that is going through copy, or there is a primary replica on the node that is copying data to some other replica. In both cases, bringing down the replica on the node due to upgrade will abort the copy.

Indicates that there is either a stateless service partition on the node having exactly one instance, or there is a primary replica on the node for which the partition is quorum loss. In both cases, bringing down the replicas due to upgrade will result in loss of availability.
Describes the upgrade phase of the corresponding node.
Indicates that the node upgrade phase is invalid. This value is not used.
Indicates that upgrade has not started on the node and Service Fabric is performing pre-upgrade safety checks.
Indicates that the node is in the process of getting upgraded.
Indicates that upgrade is complete on the node and Service Fabric is performing post-upgrade safety checks.
The safety check that is currently being performed for seed node.during upgrade

The backup option for the key-value store.
A full backup of the key-value store.
Incremental backup of the key-value store. i.e. only the log files created since the last full or incremental backup will be backed up.

member.name: F:System.Fabric.StoreBackupOption.TruncateLogsOnly

summary.para: Option to truncate the transaction logs of the key-value store without creating any backup files.

member.remarks: This is useful in avoiding creation of backup files in secondary replicas when incremental backup is turned on. If incremental backup is turned on, then disk space fills up with transaction logs of the key-value store. To prevent this, frequent backups have to be created. However, creating backups on secondary replicas may not be useful for some key-value store services. These services also have to deal with discarding the backup directory. If this option is used, it cleans up the transaction logs without creating backup files.

member.name: M:System.Fabric.DeploymentManager.AddNodeAsyncInternal(System.String,System.String,System.String,System.String,System.String,System.String,System.Fabric.FabricClient)
member.summary: This method allows a cluster administrator to add a node to a multi-machine cluster. The node connects to the cluster to get the cluster information and uses that information to join this new machine to the cluster. The API takes the name of the node, its type, ip address or fqdn, upgrade domain, fault domain and fabric package source path. It takes a FabricClient to connect to the cluster and get the current cluster information.
member.param: Name of the node that will be added.
Type of the node that will be added.
Ipaddress of the node that will be added.
Upgrade domain of the new node
Fault domain of the new node
Path of the cab file.
Fabric client is needed to obtain the cluster maniesft of the existing cluster.

member.name: M:System.Fabric.DeploymentManager.RemoveNodeAsyncInternal(System.Fabric.FabricClient)
member.summary: This allows a cluster administrator to safely remove a node from the cluster. It takes a fabricClient to ensure that it is safe to remove the node. To do so it invokes DeactivateNode with remove parameter before removing service fabric from the node.
member.param: Fabricclient is needed to obtain the Nodes in the cluster.

member.summary: This method generates a temp ClusterManifest.xml and InfrastructureManifest.xml from JsonClusterManifest that user inputs. It returns the cm and im path as a string list for the purpose of clean temp directory after consumption.
